Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics of Circular Macromolecules (DNA): From Single Molecules to Highly Entangled States

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: McKenna, Gregory B. / Schroeder, Charles / Anderson, Rae
Proposal Number: 1603943/ 1604038 / 1603925

The goal of this proposal is to explore the behavior of polymer molecules that form large ring, instead of the usual linear polymer molecules. Such polymers, example of which can be the DNA molecule, behave in a different way than linear molecules when processed or when they flow in a solution, because there are not ends in the chains. Results of this work can lead to improved polymer materials, to understanding in detail the behavior of bio-molecules and to new technologies for DNA sequencing.


Circular polymers are fascinating materials that have inspired polymer theorists and experimentalists for decades. The dynamics of circular chains differ fundamentally from their linear counterparts due to the absence of chain ends. Despite recent progress, however, the effects of circular topology on polymer dynamics remain a key unresolved problem in the field. In this proposal, the PIs are poised to make major progress in our understanding by preparing circular and linear DNA molecules that are monodisperse and of high topological purity. The assembled team has the expertise to synthesize and characterize circular and linear DNA, and will study the rheological behavior of these materials over a wider range of concentrations and molecular weights than previously achieved. A comprehensive approach is proposed that will include macroscopic and micro-rheology, single molecule polymer dynamics, and DNA synthesis, to provide new information regarding the dynamics of linear and circular DNA. Beyond providing a point of departure for understanding their circular counterparts, the parallel study of linear entangled DNA will provide unprecedented data using perfectly monodisperse DNA samples to directly test predictions from reptation theory, such as the cross-over to reptative behavior at extremely high entanglement densities. In addition to graduate student participation, educational activities are proposed in all three collaborating institutions, ranging from underrepresented minority student involvement at Texas Tech, to high school teacher engagement at Illinois and undergraduate student participation at the U of San Diego, a mainly undergraduate institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has been over a half-century since the rapid growth of synthetic materials spurred the mass production of polymers on an industrial scale. The development of synthetic materials has made a tremendous impact on society and the quality of life for large human populations. However, as society progresses, we strive to discover and develop new synthetic materials with enhanced capabilities, including materials that can be easily recycled or show triggered or controlled degradation properties. This funded project aids in the development and understanding of new materials based on circular or ring polymers. Ring polymers are unique materials that have inspired scientists and engineers for decades. Ring polymers show fundamentally different properties compared to linear polymers due to the lack of chain ends. Despite recent progress, the effects of circular topology on processing dynamics and bulk-scale properties remain a key unsolved problem in the field.

Intellectual merit: This funded project has provided an improved understanding of ring polymer dynamics that open new avenues in harnessing the unique properties of ring-shaped macromolecules for the development of new materials. From a practical perspective, our work provides the potential to unlock new classes of materials for 2-D and 3-D printing applications, additive manufacturing, or responsive or recyclable plastics based on ring chain topologies. In this funded project, the PIs made significant progress in advancing our understanding of the dynamics of ring polymers by synthesizing and studying both circular and linear polymers with precisely defined shapes and sizes (using well defined samples) and with shape purity. DNA is used as a model polymer chain due to the ability to precisely control size and shape, in addition to the ability to directly observe single DNA polymers at the molecular level. This collaborative NSF award unites three PIs with complementary expertise in bulk rheology (McKenna), single polymer dynamics (Schroeder), and DNA microrheology (Robertson-Anderson) to understand the properties of ring polymers at the molecular scale. Our team has addressed a major open question in the field of polymer dynamics: how does polymer architecture (ring versus linear) impact the flow properties of dilute, semidilute, and concentrated (entangled) systems of circular chains? In this way, our work has focused on understanding the dynamics of ring polymers over a wide range of concentrations from the ultradilute into the nominally highly entangled regime. Major activities from PI Schroeder's group for this award include the following efforts: (1) single polymer experiments focusing on the relaxation of linear polymers in lightly entangled solutions (published in Physical Review Letters), (2) single polymer experiments focusing on relaxation of rings in background solutions of linear polymers (published in Nature Communications), (3) single polymer dynamics experiments for ring polymers in background solutions of linear chains (published in Nature Communications), (4) single polymer stretching dynamics for ring polymers in background solutions of ring/linear blends, (5) design and development of a new flow apparatuses for single polymer dynamics (published in Physics of Fluids and elsewhere), (6) single polymer dynamics of ring polymers in dilute solution shear flow, including both flow-gradient and flow-vorticity directions, and (7) pioneering the study of a new chemistry for ring polymers based on a synthetic polymer with a low ceiling temperature, which holds the potential to provide extremely pure samples of ring polymers with triggered degradation properties. Broadly, this funded project has resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications, including several first-author papers by Ph.D. students in the PI's group, in Physical Review Letters, Nature Communications, Physics of Fluids, Journal of Rheology, Soft Matter, and Physical Review Research. Funded work on this award received broad coverage in the scientific press andwas highlighted on the main homepage for the National Science Foundation. Broader Impacts: Single polymer dynamics relies on scientific concepts from several diverse fields, including fluid dynanics, rheology, materials science, fluorescence microscopy, and chemical synthesis. The nature of our work provides an ideal interdisciplinary environment for training students. Graduate and undergraduate students were trained to work in a collaborative workspace with several team members from diverse scientific backgrounds. In addition, our work was included in several scientific outreach activities, including a summer educational camp for high-school girls (Worldwide Youth in Science and Engineering Program, formerly known as the GAMES Camp) and an engineering open house at the Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology.
